title: Gaps and Clusters
question_text:
Thinking about distributions that show gaps or clusters, which of the statements is true?

I. When there are multiple clusters in a distribution it is most appropriate to use the mean as the measure of center.
II. Gaps in distributions are caused by poor data collection procedures.
III. A distribution composed of multiple subgroups does not always show clusters in its histogram.
solution:
Statement I is false. When there are multiple clusters it is most appropriate to state the approximate centers of each of the clusters.

Statement II is false. Gaps are not a result of poor data collection. Gaps simply mean that there were no measurements observed for that range of possibilities.

Statement III is true. A histogram will only show clusters if the subgroups are remarkably different from each other with respect to the variable being measured.

For example, a histogram of people's ages would show multiple clusters if the subgroups of students and teachers are displayed in the same histogram.

On the other hand, a histogram of the number of movies seen per year would not show multiple clusters for students and teachers.
